MCC'S purpose is to respond to basic human needs and work for peace and justice in Canada and around the world. In support of its program work in the area of disaster/war relief, in the past years MCC wanted the Government of Canada to sign and ratify the Arms Trade Treaty, and to increase humanitarian assistance for displaced peoples in the Middle East and invest in nonmilitary means of addressing insecurity in Syria and Iraq. MCC also wanted the Government of Canada to support international efforts to ensure building materials are permitted into Gaza for reconstruction of crucial infrastructure. In support of its program work in the area of social services, in the past years MCC wanted the Government of Canada to increase its aid budget and strengthen support for small-holder farmers, implement the Calls to Action from the final report of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission, address the continuing reality of missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls and invest in restorative approaches to public safety by supporting such things as correctional programs, both during incarceration and after release, that work to rehabilitate high-risk individuals. Finally, MCC wanted the Government of Canada to increase its refugee resettlement efforts (including for Syrian refugees), and to ensure refugee claimants and others with precarious status do not face barriers to accessing support.

Laws, policies or decisions of government that GSA tried to influence through public engagement and direct requests to government in the fiscal period include preventing the expansion of fossil fuel exports which would fuel climate change, increase the risk of spills in the Strait, and lead to degradation of the Strait of Georgia; these were focused on the Kinder Morgan pipeline expansion as well other projects proposed within the transboundary waters of the Salish Sea. We highlighted the increased risk of tanker spills and the inadequacies of spill repsonse capabilities, encouraged further action to reach greenhouse gas targets and cobat climate change, encouraged a more robust assessment of shipping, the threats for port expansions in sensitive areas, better environmental assessments processes, and the need for climate accountability from the oil and gas sector. We worked to increase protection of species at risk, specifically urgent action pertaing to the southern resident ocras and chinook salmon, and actions to reduce ocean noise in the region. We promoted marine planning in the sourthern Strait through the proposed designation of an NMCA. We promoted the ongoing threats from open-net cage salmon farms and actions to remove them from areas of BC'S coast. We raised concerns about the growing impacts of shipping and anchorages on at risks species and communities, and efforts to bring international best practices around shipping to the region. GSA is involved in reducing the amount of sewage released into Georgia Strait from recreational bats and supporting stronger leadership on the threats from derelict vessels. Our purpose is to identify threats to the region and educate the public on the value of the health of the Strait, to encourage individual and collective responsibiltiy to stop further degradation and to commence protective and restorative measures.

The annual Building Bridges event brings people, from throughout the community of Guelph, together to celebrate shared values of inclusion, diversity, and mutual respect. This event helps fortify relationships between organizations working toward a common goal and vision of bettering the city for all residents and that of Muslims within the community. Building Bridges does this by providing a safe and inclusive setting in which participants can freely share ideas and perspectives, thereby alleviating stereotypes and prejudices, addressing the growing impact of online hate and intolerance, while also facilitating awareness and understanding.Participants are also provided a unique opportunity to interact with local artists that bridge approaches from within an Islamic heritage with that of a context of a multicultural Canada  helping challenge misconceptions and learning about a shared community through the perspectives of others. Participants at this event include people of different faith-based communities and cultural organizations, as well as representatives of social service agencies and non-governmental organizations. Representatives from municipal, provincial, federal levels of government are also welcome and expected to participate. The number of participants is anticipated to be upwards of 300 people.A crucial part of the Building Bridges event is to help connect often-marginalized groups with an opportunity to interact and engage with various organizations and governments. This event also helps participants develop an understanding of the different challenges and existing disparities experienced by many from within groups while helping support the sharing of "big ideas" on civic engagement and to approach overcoming these problems. In addition to the direct interaction amongst participants, invited artists, researchers/academics, and community leaders share their thoughts and perspectives on how to recognize these challenges as well as provide insight into building a better, more-inclusive community.The Building Bridges event provides the City of Guelph, and surrounding area, its only formal forum in which organizations, communities, and representatives of different levels of government, and residents at large have an opportunity to meet and explore ideas of muliticulturalism, inclusion, equity, and diversity.
